entities.trees

Class TDP_Problem_Instance

  • java.lang.Object
    • entities.trees.TDP_Problem_Instance
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    TDP_BinaryStar_Equijoin_Instance, TDP_Star_Equijoin_Instance

    public abstract class TDP_Problem_Instance
extends Object
    An instance of a T-DP problem realized as a multi-stage graph of state-nodes where the stages are organized in a tree structure. The edges between those nodes specify the dependencies between them. There is a starting node and mutiple terminal nodes (the leaves of the tree). The terminal node is not explicitly materialized - we assume that all the nodes of the last stage reach it with no cost. A solution to the T-DP problem is a tree from the source node to the terminal nodes. We assume that the stages are indexed consistently with the tree order, i.e., if Si has child Sj then j > i. This is an abstract class that captures all T-DP problems. An implementing subclass has to initialize the stages and the nodes by providing an implementation for the abstract method bottom_up(). This method has to:
    • Instantiate nodes as TDP_State_Node objects.
    • Set a single node as starting_node.
    • Set a number of nodes as terminals (those that belong to leaf stages).
    • Define the tree structure by using add_stage_to_tree(java.lang.Integer, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>).
    • Instantiate weighted edges between them as TDP_Decision.
    • Compute the minimum achievable weight per node.

    Note: Contrary to the classes in entities.paths, the bottom-up phase here is not decoupled from the graph construction: these happen simultaneously (e.g. see TDP_DecisionSet.add(entities.trees.TDP_Decision)).
    Author:
    Nikolaos Tziavelis

      private List<Integer> branch_index
      An auxiliary data structure that stores the index of a stage as a branch from its parent For example stage 2 could have 3 children stages: 5, 6, 7.
      private List<Integer> parents
      An auxiliary data structure that encodes the tree with reverse edges, i.e., it gives us the parent of each stage (its index).

      A data structure (similar to an adjacency list) that stores the tree structure of the problem.

      The T-DP states are partitioned in stages.
      int stages_no
      The number of stages of the T-DP problem.

      Single source node located at stage 0.

    • Field Detail

      • starting_node

        public TDP_State_Node starting_node
        Single source node located at stage 0.

      • stages

        List<List<TDP_State_Node>> stages
        The T-DP states are partitioned in stages.

      • stages_no

        public int stages_no
        The number of stages of the T-DP problem. Includes the starting stage (but not the terminal ones).

      • stage_tree

        private List<List<Integer>> stage_tree
        A data structure (similar to an adjacency list) that stores the tree structure of the problem. Every stage has a unique index and the list element with that index gives us the indexes of its children.

      • parents

        private List<Integer> parents
        An auxiliary data structure that encodes the tree with reverse edges, i.e., it gives us the parent of each stage (its index).

      • branch_index

        private List<Integer> branch_index
        An auxiliary data structure that stores the index of a stage as a branch from its parent For example stage 2 could have 3 children stages: 5, 6, 7. Then the branch index of 6 is 1.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TDP_Problem_Instance

        public TDP_Problem_Instance(int num_of_stages)
        Parameters:
        num_of_stages - The number of the stages the T-DP problem will have. Includes the starting stage (but not the terminal ones).

    • Method Detail

      • bottom_up

        public abstract void bottom_up()
        The bottom-up phase of T-DP creates a T-DP state/node for each tuple. Every relation maps to a stage of T-DP. The starting node is artificial and the terminal nodes are implicit (To avoid the unnecessary overhead, we omit the terminal nodes). The cost of transitioning to a tuple is the cost of that tuple. After the bottom-up phase, the optimal cost is the minimum achievable cost from starting_node. The optimal (top-1) solution can be reconstructed by going top-down and following best decisions.

      • add_stage_to_tree

        protected void add_stage_to_tree(Integer stage,
                                 List<Integer> children_stages)
        Adds a stage to the tree and updates all the necessary data structures.
        Parameters:
        stage - The index of the stage to be added.
        children_stages - THe indexes of its children.

      • get_children_stages

        public List<Integer> get_children_stages(int stage)
        Parameters:
        stage - The index of a T-DP stage.
        Returns:
        List The indexes of its children stages or an empty list if it is a leaf stage.

      • get_parent_stage

        public Integer get_parent_stage(int stage)
        Returns the parent stage of a particular stage
        Parameters:
        stage - The index of a T-DP stage.
        Returns:
        Integer The index of its parent or null for the root (0).

        See Also:

      • print_edges

        public void print_edges()
        Use this after the bottom-up phase to print all the feasible decisions between the state nodes. Feasible decisions = edges that lead to a node that can reach the terminal states.
